title: Best vitamin D supplement 2023: Support your mental wellbeing this winter
author: Anna Gora
description: The best vitamin D supplement is an easy way to support your physical and mental health during the winter months
cleaned_text: Best vitamin D supplement 2023: Support your mental wellbeing this winter [References](https://www.livescience.com/references) [Anna Gora](https://www.livescience.com/author/anna-gora) The best vitamin D supplement is an easy way to support your physical and mental health during the winter months Is now a good time to invest in the best vitamin D supplement? Without a doubt. With the fall season in full swing, we are more likely to struggle with getting enough of this crucial nutrient. Our skin naturally synthesizes [vitamin D](https://www.livescience.com/42481-vitamin-d-supplement-facts.html) in response to sunlight, which is why it is known as the sunshine vitamin. But when days get darker, our bodies may not be able to produce enough of it. Thankfully, supplements help us bridge this gap and avoid a potential vitamin D deficiency. There are many ways in which vitamin D can keep our health in check. To start with, it is involved in the regulation of [calcium](https://www.livescience.com/29070-calcium.html) and phosphorus metabolism. This in turn has a massive impact on bone health. In fact, vitamin D deficiency can lead to several bone diseases, such as rickets in children, and osteomalacia (bone pain) in adults. Getting enough of this vital nutrient helps reduce inflammation and [boost our immune system](https://www.livescience.com/which-vitamins-boost-the-immune-system), as well as [improves sports performance and reduces risk of injury](https://www.livescience.com/63959-vitamin-d-fitness.html). Some [studies](https://doi.org/10.1192/bjp.bp.111.106666) even suggest that this nutrient can boost our mood. According to the [NIH](https://ods.od.nih.gov/factsheets/VitaminD-HealthProfessional/), the recommended dietary allowance (RDA) for vitamin D in the U.S. is 15 mcg (600 IU) for adults and children aged one and older, rising to 20 mcg (800 IU) for those over the age of 70. Although we can obtain this nutrient from diet, the list of [vitamin D sources](https://www.livescience.com/six-sources-of-vitamin-d) is relatively short, and mostly comes from animal-based products, mushrooms and fortified foods. Many may struggle with including enough of these foods in their diet, especially if they are vegan or vegetarian. People with certain digestive disorders are also at higher risk of developing deficiency, as well as older adults and people with dark skin. So if you want to top up your intake of the sunshine vitamin, but aren't sure which supplement may be worth investing in, keep reading. We've tried and tested multiple different vitamin D capsules, sprays, and chewables so you can find the best option for you. Best vitamin D supplement 1. Vitamin D3 vs D2 Vitamin D supplements are available in two forms: D2, known as ergocalciferol, and D3, known as cholecalciferol. Vitamin D3 is found largely in animal-based foods, such as oily fish, eggs and butter. The only plant that contains this form is lichen, an algae-fungal hybrid microorganism that grows on trees and stones. Vitamin D2, on the other hand, comes mostly from dietary supplements, fortified foods, and mushrooms grown in UV light. Both of these chemical compounds contribute to your daily vitamin D requirements, but they may have a slightly different effect on our bodies. According to the researchers from [The American Journal of Clinical Nutrition](https://doi.org/10.3945%2Fajcn.111.031070), vitamin D3 supplements are generally better than the ones with vitamin D2 at raising the blood serum vitamin D levels. As such, products containing cholecalciferol may be more cost-effective. How much vitamin D should I take? Vitamin D content and Recommended Daily Allowance (RDA) reference points are usually listed in both micrograms (mcg) and international units (IU). One microgram of this nutrient is equal to 40 IU. The [National Institutes of Health](https://ods.od.nih.gov/factsheets/VitaminD-Consumer/) recommends an average daily intake of 400-800 IU (10-20 micrograms) of vitamin D. It also advises not to exceed the 4000 IU (100 micrograms) level, because such a high dosage may pose a risk to your health. There are certain population groups that could benefit from stronger vitamin D supplements. These include older adults and individuals with darker skin tones, as mentioned in [The Journal of Nutrition](https://doi.org/10.1093/jn/136.4.1126). Those who are overweight and obese also tend to be more deficient in this nutrient, as described in the [European Journal of Nutrition](https://doi.org/10.1007/s00394-013-0634-3). Researchers from the [PLoS One](https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pone.0111265) propose that vitamin D supplementation should be two to three times higher for obese individuals and 1.5 times higher for those considered overweight. Which vitamin D supplement is best? Dietary supplements are not as tightly regulated as pharmaceuticals, so it may be tricky to know if you are buying a good one. So how to recognize a good quality product? The best vitamin D supplements adhere to all relevant Food and Drug Administration (FDA) regulations, including allowable health claims and labeling requirements. They are manufactured in facilities that follow current good manufacturing practices (CGMPs). To ensure that a supplement is sold by a reputable company that follows ethical, legal, and industry best standards, check whether it has any third-party certifications. These may include approvals from NSF, Consumer Lab and United States Pharmacopeial Convention. Vitamin D supplements come in many different forms, including chewable tablets, liquids, and sprays, making it easy to pick a product that suits your preferences and medical needs. For example, fortified gummies may be more appealing to fussy children, while a liquid or a spray may be easier to take for people with certain health conditions. It is also worth checking whether your vitamin D supplement contains oils. Since this nutrient dissolves in fats, an oil-based formula could help improve its absorption in your digestive tract. How do we test vitamin D supplements at Live Science? All of the supplements in this guide have been tried and tested by the Live Science team. Supplements will affect everyone slightly differently, so we review our products based on what they contain and what you might need to be aware of before taking them. We focus on the following areas in particular: Ingredients: We note exactly what ingredients are in a vitamin D supplement. We then compare this to your recommended daily value so you can decipher if you'll get enough cholecalciferol from these supplements. Recommended dosage In all of our reviews, we note how much of each supplement you are required to take and how often. Suitability We recognise that different people have different needs. We make clear if a vitamin D supplement is suitable for a particular diet (such as vegan or gluten-free). We also note if it is GMO-friendly or suitable for people with particular allergies. Easiness to swallow & taste Because we test every supplement ourselves, we make sure to disclose whether the supplements are easy to swallow. While taste is subjective, we do make note of this too, including any unpleasant aftertastes. Extra features When we test vitamin D supplements, we note if one thing makes it stand out over the other. This could be the bioavailability of the ingredient or the manufacturing methods.
